Koe_Wetzel:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Koe Wetzel | image = Koe Wetzel in 2017.png | caption = Wetzel in 2017 | birth_name = Ropyr Madison Koe Wetzel | birth_place = [[Pittsburg, Texas]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1992|07|14}} | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Country rock]] * [[alternative country]] * [[alternative rock]] * [[outlaw country]] * [[hard rock]] * [[grunge]]{{Cite web|last=Stefano|first=Angela|date=2020-11-20|title=Interview: Koe Wetzel Sticks to His Guns on First Major-Label Album, 'Sellout'|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/koe-wetzel-sellout-album-interview-2020/|access-date=2021-07-01|website=Taste of Country|language=en}} * [[post-grunge]]}} | website = {{URL|https://koewetzelmusic.com/}} }} '''Ropyr Madison Koe Wetzel'''{{Cite web|last=Durchholz|first=Daniel|title=Outlaw country artist Koe Wetzel has moved to a major label, but don't call him a sellout|url=https://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/outlaw-country-artist-koe-wetzel-has-moved-to-a-major-label-but-dont-call-him/article_42c37a67-cce1-5cd1-9387-024c5bcbd46d.html|access-date=2021-07-01|website=STLtoday.com|date=16 June 2021 |publisher=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]|language=en}} (born July 14, 1992){{Cite web|title=Koe's Black & Red Birthday Bash|url=https://dailytexascountry.com/posts/koes-black-&-red-birthday-bash|access-date=2021-07-01|website=dailytexascountry.com|language=en}} is an American singer and songwriter. His music has been described variously as a "blend of rock and country",{{Cite web|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|date=2021-06-22|title=Texas Artist Koe Wetzel Talks His First Major Label Album: "We're Not Going To Change for Anybody"|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1835312/texas-artist-koe-wetzel-talks-his-first-major-label-album-were-not-going-to-change-for-anybody/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210623010011/http://www.cmt.com/news/1835312/texas-artist-koe-wetzel-talks-his-first-major-label-album-were-not-going-to-change-for-anybody/|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 23, 2021|access-date=2021-07-01|website=CMT News}} [[outlaw country]],{{Cite web|last=Kent|first=Roy|date=2021-06-04|title=Country music artist Koe Wetzel to perform July 3 at Constellation Field in Sugar Land|url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/neighborhood/sugarland/article/Country-music-artist-Koe-Wetzel-to-perform-July-3-16225144.php|access-date=2021-07-01|website=Houston Chronicle|language=en-US}} and "fusing country and [[grunge]]".{{Cite web|last=Stefano|first=Angela|date=2020-11-20|title=Interview: Koe Wetzel Sticks to His Guns on First Major-Label Album, 'Sellout'|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/koe-wetzel-sellout-album-interview-2020/|access-date=2021-07-01|website=Taste of Country|language=en}} == Life and career == Wetzel was born in [[Pittsburg, Texas]], with one of his names being a reference to outlaw country singer-songwriter [[David Allan Coe]]. His mother was a touring country singer, bringing the young Koe along and his father worked in construction. He would perform on stage for the first time at age six. Later, Wetzel was a [[linebacker]] at [[Tarleton State University]] in [[Stephenville, Texas]], where he decided to pursue a career as a musician instead. Wetzel formed "Koe Wetzel and Konvicts", and self-released an EP and one full-length album. His "rowdy" music and lyrics became popular among college students and young adults, and ''Noise Complaint,'' released in 2016, was considered to be his breakout album.{{Cite web|last=Deming|first=Mark|title=Koe Wetzel: Biography & History|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/koe-wetzel-mn0003724456/biography|access-date=2021-07-02|website=AllMusic|language=en}} Beginning with ''Noise Complaint'', the full name of the band was dropped, though Wetzel still performs with a bassist, one drummer, and two guitarists.{{Cite web|title=KOE WETZEL|url=https://www.chilifest.org/koe-wetzel/|access-date=2021-07-02|website=Chilifest 2020 Official Website|language=en-US}} The band signed with Red 11 Music in Austin, TX in early 2018 while being managed by 4-Tay Management out of Stephenville, TX until 2019 when the band signed a management deal with Floating Leaf Entertainment, establishing a joint venture between Wetzel and Jeb Hurt who had previously been the band's agent at Red 11 Music. ''Harold Saul High'' was released in 2019,{{Cite web|last=Fox|first=Chris|date=2019-06-19|title=Koe Wetzel Earns High Marks in "Harold Saul High" {{!}}|url=http://texasmusicpickers.com/koe-wetzel-earns-high-marks-in-harold-saul-high/|access-date=2021-07-02|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|last=Kephart|first=Zackary|date=2019-06-27|title=Album Review: Koe Wetzel – 'Harold Saul High'|url=https://themusicaldivide.com/2019/06/27/album-review-koe-wetzel-harold-saul-high/|access-date=2021-07-02|website=The Musical Divide|language=en}} however sales were strong, and the album charted on the [[Billboard 200]]. In 2020, Wetzel released ''Sellout'', named in reference to his signing with major label [[Columbia Records]].{{Cite web|date=2020-12-01|title=Koe Wetzel Reassures the Masses That He'll Never Change on 'Sellout'|url=https://americansongwriter.com/koe-wetzel-reassures-the-masses-that-hell-never-change-on-sellout/|access-date=2021-07-02|website=American Songwriter|language=en-US}} In 2023, Wetzel became{{Cite web|date=2023-01-19|title=Fort Worth hospitality vets partner with musician Koe Wetzel on new country venue|url=https://fortworth.culturemap.com/news/restaurants-bars/koe-wetzel-riot-room-emil-bragdon/|access-date=2024-05-08|website=CultureMap Fort Worth|language=en-US}} a partner in the opening of a highly successful restaurant-bar and live music review in Fort Worth, Texas called Koe Wetzel's Riot Room. == Musical style == Wetzel's music is usually described as fusing genres, especially rock and country while he has been rumored to personally refer to his blend of music as "Hillbilly Punk-Rock". In his youth, Wetzel was exposed to country, hip-hop, rap, and grunge including the music of [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]]. In an interview for ''[[American Songwriter]]'', Wetzel described his album ''Harold Saul High'' as "...90s country meets early 2000s [[punk rock]] with early ’90s [[grunge]] and [[Hip hop music|hip-hop]] music in the background." His lyrics often deal with mature subject matter, and are known for containing explicit language. One example is the song "February 28, 2016": a song about drunkenness, and a reference to his arrest for [[public intoxication]] in Stephenville on that day.{{Cite web|last=Langeler|first=Wes|date=2021-02-28|title=Happy February 28th, AKA Koe Wetzel Day|url=https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2021/02/28/happy-february-28th-aka-koe-wetzel-day/|access-date=2021-07-01|website=Whiskey Riff|language=en-US}} In 2019, Wetzel's performance at the [[Great Texas Balloon Race]] was the subject of some controversy, after some festival goers were offended at his refusal to make his songs more family friendly. Wetzel responded in a [[Tongue-in-cheek|tongue in cheek]] manner, taking credit for breaking attendance records.{{Cite web|date=2019-07-30|title=Koe Wetzel throws shade at Great Texas Balloon Race over apology|url=https://www.ketk.com/news/local-news/koe-wetzel-throws-shade-at-great-texas-balloon-race-over-apology/|access-date=2021-07-01|website=KETK.com {{!}} FOX51.com|language=en-US}} == Discography == === Studio albums === {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |+ List of studio albums, with selected details and chart positions !scope="col" rowspan="2"|Title !scope="col" rowspan="2"|Album details{{Cite web|title=Koe Wetzel and the Konvicts Songs|url=http://www.reverbnation.com/koewetzelandthekonvicts/songs|access-date=2021-07-02|website=ReverbNation|language=en}} !scope="col" colspan="3"|Peak chart positions |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em; font-size:85%"| [[Billboard 200|US]]
